Acting On Plastic Waste, Gurudwara Bangla Sahib Bans Use Of All Kinds Of Plastic Items Inside Premises

In a bid to tackle plastic waste, Bangla Sahib Gurdwara has banned the use of all kinds of plastic items within the shrine complex.

The decision has been taken as part of programmes to commemorate 550th birth anniversary of Guru Nanak Dev, Manjinder Singh Sirsa, president of the Delhi Sikh Gurdwara Management Committee (DSGMC) told PTI.

Disposable plates, glasses, spoons, thermocol cup-plates and other single-use plastics have been banned by the biggest gurdwara in the national capital. The Sikh shrine has switched to steel utensils for serving water and ‘langar’ (community meal) to devotees.

BCCL

“On an average, around 5,000 poly bags and thermocol cup-plates were used every day to distribute prasad, fruits and other items to devotees. Now these have been replaced with eco-friendly jute bags, and dona-pattal (leaf bowls and plates) since October 2,” Sirsa said.

A recycling plant capable of handling two tonnes of flower and ‘lanagar’ waste, and dry leaves daily has also been set up. The organic waste is converted into manure and vermicompost.

BCCL

The fully automatic plant has been commissioned on an experimental basis at present to experiment with the zero-waste model and will be commissioned on full scale during current month, Sirsa said.

Additionally, the DSGMC has completely shifted to clean piped natural gas for preparing ‘langar’ for around 35,000 people per day, completely banning the use of woof and charcoal for cooking.
